title: Westpac the target as equities teams, investors chase banks
text:
The quickest and cleanest way for the banks to hit capital targets would be to raise fresh funds. It last happened in 2015, when each of the big four went to investors in the space of five months.

Equity markets are wide open for follow-on raisings, especially from blue chip companies; Macquarie, Transurban, Mirvac, DEXUS and GPT have proved that in the past six months. There was even support for the troubled AMP.

An institutional placement, arranged overnight and run during the course of one trading day, could instantly get any one of the banks to its required Tier 1 capital ratio. Add a discounted share purchase plan for existing investors and everyone would walk away happy.

Westpac Banking Corp is seen as most likely to go for the instant fix. It and National Australia Bank are front of the queue for capital remedies, while ANZ is more likely to await confirmation of capital changes across the Tasman.

Westpac's cleansing release to market this week detailed that it had provisioned a further $341 million after tax for the ongoing refund initiative in the second half of the 2019 financial year. Sam Mooy

Investment bankers and investors are known to be positioning for such a situation. And, a week or two out from reporting dates, the banks are keeping their options open.

The more conservative route would be to underwrite a DRP, which could easily raise $2 billion or more this side of Christmas. Each of the big investment banks would be willing to stump up its balance sheet to underwrite such a deal – albeit with much less enthusiasm than a fee-rich equity raising.

Perhaps the most obvious – and logical – solution to the banks' capital quandary is to cut the dividend. But as everyone knows, that's also not without risk in a market buying bank stocks for their yield. And what CEO or chairman wants a tanking share price?
description: Move over IPOs, there's a new equity capital markets game in town.
